We are not lucky to be govt employees. We are lucky to be paid to do what we love, and we have a responsibility to spend public money well.

Very excited about the release of #cryoSPARC v2! This has been a long time in the making and the @structurabio team has put in a ton of work and it has paid off. With full pipeline processing, cluster support and more v2 delivers on the promise of new algorithms in practice. https:// twitter.com/structurabio/s tatus/1030482541814403072 …

+amen to that...forked a repo just so I can read through it occasionally when I'm tired of looking at my own : ) Relion's source also instructive over the years. Comments on sinc vs Kaiser blob in recon comes to mind

I think you'll find the Structura business model will continue to evolve as the terrain changes I have confidence that this combination of expertise in a tech startup have a valuable contribution to make But at this stage the runway is very short and it may be a rocky takeoff
I concur. Hopefully, @ccp_em can play a role in this, where the @ccp4_mx model can play as example. Pharma pays, but science is also served.
Yup, ease of use will be king once everything else becomes equal. I want the software that will enable me to have an interactive graphical conversation with my data. And then I want it in VR

I imagine most GUIs in #cryoEM software could be made non-GPL without stepping on anyone's toes. As the field matures, ease of use becomes an equally important feature as the computational back end. Maybe something to consider when thinking about competitive advantages.

You can't change it retroactively, but you can change it for future versions. You can also release it under different licenses in parallel, e. g. grant some company the right to make a closed-source derivative. All of this requires clean separation of parts you haven't authored.
And it is a joy seeing your code on GitHub! This way, you also allow others to build on your work, hence optimally advancing science.
Would that even be allowed? First release under a GPL and then change the license? I thought once something is GPL, it will always remain so...

You'd have to cleanly separate all the Xmipp and Bsoft code before you could change the license for your own code parts to something that allows for discrimination between commercial and non-commercial users.

It's been a tremendous help in many of my projects and saved me months of trial & error. Thank you very much! My point was that if you, as the author, wanted to accommodate John's request, you couldn't because it's so intertwined with GPL code from other projects.
PS: everyone who gets to spend public money for science is in a privileged position. Not only those at a few highly visible institutes.

#RELION is proudly #GPL ! It benefitted from source in #Xmipp , #Bsoft and others, and its own source has helped #cryoSPARC , #sphire and hopefully more. Its main objective is to advance science, irrespective of whether it is done in an academic or commercial setting.

But, @RubinsteinJohn , I fully recognize your argument that we are in a privileged position to opine this idealistically, and I repeat my admiration for the @structurabio team. I hope they will get the balance right: funding themselves while also advancing science.

I think this requirement would be very hard to fulfill given the amount of GPL-licensed code. Easy to avoid in something small and isolated like MotionCor2, but RELION and others are built on that stuff. One could, at most, limit free user support to academia.

If the IP is instead know how" or "trade secret" you must never publish or make it public, to academics or other, without NDAs or your IP is void. These are very different scenarios which lead to different business models, licenses etc."

It is indeed a delicate balance. The IP approach is by far the best - but requires buy-in from other authors because nothing would be worse for the field than trying to enforce IP in an adversarial situation. Leave that to CRISPR.

I'm unclear on the type of IP here. If the algorithms are patented the inventor is obliged to publish them and you can structrure the licenses anyway you wish, including free for non-commercial use and fees for commercial use. No one else can reimplemet" for profit till expiry."
Or at least excluding the components based on IP protected approaches from the versions given for free to commercial users.
Indeed I misread. Oops. So you're basically suggesting all packages in the field should start charging for commercial use. Interesting proposition.
Or limitation of 280 characters: can reimplement for academic use but the reimplementation could not be given for free to commercial users.

I think that's fine. Protect the engineering, not the science. But I'd wager less licenses would be sold if free but slightly slower alternative available, so I really worry that there is incentive for secrecy and less reproducibility, beyond just the engineering.
I think you misread - academia can reproduce it. But not reproduce it for commercial use.

Algorithm can indeed be described in enough detail for implementation - but the engineering of getting it fast/power (which isn't the algorithm itself) need not be described. I understand how FFTs work - I don't really get how FFTW is so absurdly fast.
How is it not stifling science if the hope and stated purpose is that academia will not reproduce your results? Can't have it both ways.

Structura has always stated the purpose of its IP was not to stifle academic development. But reimplementing algs and giving to commercial users would kill the startup's market and thus the startup. So can't do that and then turn around and cry foul on closed source.
#2 also implies that algorithms not be described in enough details in publications for reproduction by others. Else you're back at #1. This is part of the problem.

Scenarios 1) code w/ novel algs released, grant-funded software rewrites algs & gives to commercial users, startup fails 2) code not released, startup has chance 3) code released but grant funded agree not to rewrite/give away algs #3 best but needs goodwill. IP already in place

Look, I personally think the folks @structurabio are doing fantastic work and I am thrilled they are using their knowledge to improve cryoEM for many. But I'm not convinced a closed-source business model is good for them, their investors, or the field.
Hmmmmm, interesting
If you or anyone has ideas of such project, you should definitely approach your friendly industry colleagues ;) Seriously, do.
Cite the tweet?
I'm writing up a structure solved w/ cryoSPARC 2, how should I cite it? Punjani personal communication?
There actually has been clear evidence it would. That's why decision to stop releasing source was just made now, not ver 1.

If Structura fails even cryoSPARC will not be able to build on cryoSPARC. Nothing safe about cryoSPARC. Safety is $ from enlightened institute or agency that sees value in supporting code for community Could happen one day with cryoSPARC but not even clear it's possible here

To be fair, the only previous example of successful #cryoEM software commercialization – @Marin_van_Heel 's IMAGIC – has been closed-source. Personally, I'd much rather see the industry provide more scholarship options to finance academic projects they might benefit from.
That said, I also cheer on the #cryoSPARC team! They are great scientists who contribute highly original and fresh ideas that the field was really in need of.

Closed source hinders further development. This may feel safer, but slows down progress. #relion built on open source of #xmipp & #bsoft . #cryosparc_v1 built on #relion . #relion_v3 built on #cryosparc_v1 . Who will build on #cryosparc_v2 , #motioncor2 & #gctf ?

And I don't think it's just three academics cheering them on!!! I think the whole field benefits enormously by having more software makers. So long as friendly competition and cross pollination of ideas continues, the field benefits.

I think the original comment by @biochem_fan that triggered all this was that without the source it is difficult to know precisely what is going on and reproducibility goes down. I am still not convinced that cryoSPARC would lose license income if they open sourced.

The ideas and algorithms will all be published. The proprietary code protects the value added - the engineering that makes the algorithms fast, robust, and easy to use. Entire @structurabio team paid by revenue from licenses - enthusiastically cheered on by three academics
Fair enough. And you really think cryoSPARC would not survive open sourcing? The way I see it, they could (and already do) add a lot of value beyond the basic ideas and algorithms.

From http://www. phenix-online.org / : Funding for PHENIX: NIH General Medical Sciences" http://www. ccp4.ac.uk : acknowledges @BBSRC and @The_MRC Pharma may be contributing, but clearly not enough so taxpayers are subsidizing them."

Agree the team is great and are doing exceptional work. I was more asking what would make their model more susceptible to failure post open sourcing than Phenix. Am I wrong in assuming Phenix/CCP4 are doing well enough from industry fees to support developers? Honestly don't know

Team @structurabio are best-in-class comp Scis/Engs who could easily make enormous $ at Facebook/Uber/Google. No one there to get rich. There b/c believe can do something valuable in company that can't be done in academia. And yes - doing it w/o safety net of an academic salary

lol, 2.4A, nice~
We usually do this at postprocessing step (where we also apply the B-factor). Not sure whether we have the F3EC curve. Will ask around.

Here are curves for an apoferritin refinement at 2.4Å. Another Falcon3 structure (more heterogeneous res'n than apoferritin) went to 3.8Å res'n with 112.5Å**2. Do you typically correct detector MTF before processing? pic.twitter.com/OOQsC2v6Kh
Interesting. My questions about the maps we've produced so far with the F3 will have to wait. Just tried to SSH in before remembering we've turned everything off for a power-shutdown today.

I seem to remember Fei Sun's eHEC algorithm for F3 didn't improve resolution, but made the map sharper before B-factor correction – presumably by having a better MTF. So maybe there is plenty of MTF to correct in the vanilla counting algorithm.

Interesting pt. We only have a few structs with Falcon3. There's no pre-correction for MTF (as @DTegunov mentions). This is counted image - I need to think about the MTF from real-space antialiasing of FEI's EC algo. I'll investigate (and look at our other maps).
After MTF correction? (don't know what it looks like for F3EC)
That is much higher than I would expect for that resolution... I would expect half of that value
With apoferritin you can do anything!
Thanks. This is awesome!
BTW: what is your estimated B-factor?
Excellent! Who said one can't go beyond 2/3 of Nyquist?
Although, as we've been discussing on email, I'm not sure if the gain vs NRAMM's standard 2.6-2.8A is due to Falcon3, alignparts, both, or neither (maybe Samir just makes great grids).
There is an option to align frames in EPU which does drift correction between frames (in groups of 6 to boost the signal) within dose fractions.
Yes.
This is great John! Did you use EPU for data collection?
Our stage is getting better with improved temp stability. ;-)
For Falcon it's the luxury of having your own rig.
I don't know. The Falcon3EC needs a stable stage (and holder) and your Halo seems to have stability issues. Can't wait to find out about the next Falcon at some point...
Impressive! Did i upgrade to the wrong camera?
I should say: CTF determination with CTFFIND4 and particle picking with Relion 2
I am proud to say we have never collected data in linear mode - on the K2 or Falcon3
Do you have comparison data using linear mode?

Our go to" pipeline with our @feicompany G3 Krios and Falcon 3EC: 1.06 Å/pixel, 0.8 e/p/s, 30 fractions, 60 sec. Process with alignframes_lmfgs, alignparts_lmbfgs, and @structurabio cryoSPARC. Samir just collected apoferritin for 5h (71k particles), reached 2.4 Å pic.twitter.com/1bOHxlMRAa"
